III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4112 Criminal history check, subject to
Section requirements; staff qualifications. Sufficiency of Staff
Description (4) A person with ongoing duties shall have both of the following:
(a) Ability to perform duties of the position assigned.
(b) Experience to perform the duties of the position assigned.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff touches them sexually and is always in their personal space.
Investigation Licensing Consultant for the facility was interviewed via
phone on 3/7/23. She reported there are five youth in the
program identified in the allegation.
Complainant was interviewed via phone on 3/7/23. She
reported working at the facility for the past four months and having
the primary job duty of reviewing youth satisfaction surveys. She
also reported sharing the informed with her supervisor who is also
reported to have told the program administration of the concerns.
She was unable to add anything further to the allegations she
reported.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility, on
3/8/2023 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth A
reported remembering the complaint she made several months
ago that involved her claiming she was sexually touched. This was
investigated (2023C0000072) and no substantial violations were
found on 12/20/2022. Youth A denied anyone at the facility (youth
or staff) have touched her sexually since the prior complaint.
Youth B has attempted to touch Youth A, but staff have intervened
each time and Youth B is currently on a sexual safety plan. Youth
A reported feeling safe and that “things are going well” at the
facility. Youth A also reported not having enough to eat and not
being allowed more than one fruit for snack.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility, on
3/8/2023 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth B
acknowledged “chasing” other youth but not touching them
because staff have intervened. Youth B also reported feeling safe
at the facility along with being allowed to have fruit whenever they
are hungry. Youth are allowed as much fruit as they want but one
at a time.
2

Youth C was interviewed face-to-face at the facility, on
3/8/2023 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth C
reported feeling safe on the unit and having staff available to talk
with. Youth C also reported staff are always around and Youth C
has never felt uncomfortable with them. Youth C has enough to
eat and is allowed fruit for a snack whenever hungry. Youth are
also allowed several items of fruit.
Chief Administrator was interviewed face-to-face at the
facility, on 3/8/2023 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. He
reported Youth A and Youth B both have sexual safety plans and
Youth B will only target another youth when he has become
emotionally dysregulated. He reported staff have been very
successful in protecting other youth and their interventions with
Youth B have worked. He reported youth are allowed more than
one fruit for a snack but must finish the first item before getting a
second.
Shift Supervisor was interviewed face-to-face at the facility,
on 3/8/2023 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported
staff have reported Youth A claimed to have been touched by staff
and there was follow up (2023C0000072). She reported there has
been nothing recently. She has never witnessed inappropriate
touching by staff and has no concerns about this type of issue.
Staff have addressed Youth B’s dysregulation appropriately and
kept him from touching other youth. She was able to give account
in detail of the sexual safety plan for Youth A.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility, on 3/8/2023
in collaboration with MDHHS worker. He reported never
observing staff being inappropriate with any youth and never
having Youth A report inappropriate touching by staff. He
described Youth B’s behavior as becoming dysregulated and
picking someone to be mad at. He was able to recall both Youth A
and Youth B’s sexual safety plans in detail. He reported youth can
have fruit anytime they would like but one at a time.
Therapist was interviewed face-to-face at the facility, on
3/8/2023 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported
being the primary therapist for Youth A. Youth A is involved in her
treatment services and open during the therapy sessions. She
reported Youth A is doing well in the program and is scheduled to
be discharged in approximately two weeks. She denied Youth A
ever told her anything about being sexually touched but did
mention Youth B is “gross” but nothing more about Youth B.
3

Program Supervisor was interviewed via phone on 9/9/2023 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported receiving the
satisfaction survey and Youth A told her Youth A put things on the
survey that were going on in the unit. Program Supervisor asked if
Youth A was feeling safe to which Youth A laughed and said “no”.
Youth A did not explain the reasons for feeling unsafe even when
questioned again by Program Supervisor. She had no concerns
about the survey since no specific individuals or situations were
identified. She denied witnessing any inappropriate touch by staff
and believes staff handle Youth B’s dysregulation as required.
Tour Observation:
A tour of the unit Youth A is lodged in occurred. The unit was
clean and well decorated. During the tour the youth were being
served lunch and it was appropriate food in appropriate amounts.
The fruit bowl was observed and there was an offering of at least
four different types of fruit.
Documents Reviewed:
Special Investigation 2023C0000072 dated 12/20/22. The
allegations of this complaint involve Youth A reporting, “Staff will
touch or rub youth’s buttocks when they walk”. The facility was
found in compliance since none of the other youth (3) had
witnessed or experienced staff touching youth sexually or
inappropriately. All staff interviewed also denied observing any
staff touching youth inappropriately.
Personal Safety plan for Youth A dated 8/30/22. This plan
outlines six actions Youth A must engage in. These involve, her
location to others when sitting, 1:1 supervision when in the
presence of a peer, report to staff when feeling personal space is
violated, minimize inappropriate sexual comments around peers,
use appropriate body movements when dancing, and seek
feedback if not understanding directions from staff. It is also
documented staff are to seek opportunities to coach Youth A on
healthy social boundaries.
Analysis Based upon interviews there is no evidence that supports the
complaint of staff or other youth touching Youth A sexually or
inappropriately.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
4

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
